title: SL-Public Financial Management TAL (FY09
description: The objective of the Integrated Public Financial Management Reform Project is to support Government of Sierra Leone in sustainably improving the credibility, control and transparency of fiscal and budget management. There are five components to the project. The first component of the project is strengthening macro-fiscal coordination and budget management, this component will include improved budget credibility associated with a more appropriately developed and managed aggregate fiscal position, delivery by the Ministry of Finance and Economic Development (MOFED) of predictable funding in accordance with budgets, constrained Ministries, Departments, and Agencies (MDAs) budgets and control of  the in year position contributing to objectives of platform one, and improved strategic planning and prioritization contributing to objectives of platform two. The second component of the project is reinforcing the control system for improved service delivery, this component include an updated legal framework, robust public procurement practices, tightened payroll controls, strengthened internal audit, improved accounting procedures operating in the MOFED and MDAs and further publication of Public Expenditure Tracking Survey (PETS) contributing to an effective control environment in MDAs. Striving for these internal controls will be reinforced through strengthened scrutiny of public finances by Parliament. The third component of the project is strengthening central finance functions, this component will undertake various cross-cutting activities including IFMIS rollout, all aspects of training and Human Resource (HR) capacity development that are required to support the main Public Financial Management (PFM) functions. The fourth component of the project is assisting non-state actor's oversight, this component will assist the development of the analytic and dissemination capacity of non-state actors in exercising scrutiny of the use of public resources, as well as building a constituency for reform of the PFM system across an array of non-state and government actors. The fifth component of the project is project management, under this component project administration unit will be established within the MOFED and will be staffed with a project manager who will also have monitoring and evaluation responsibilities for the Integrated Public Financial Management Reform Project (IPFMRP), a procurement specialist and a project accountant.

description: This project paper introduces the following changes in the Sierra Leone Rural and Private Sector Development Project and related amendments to the project's legal documents. The modification will involve: (i) changes in the project implementation arrangements; (ii) reallocation of grant proceeds to cater for increased support towards rehabilitation of feeder roads; (iii) modifications to the project development objective (PDO) for clarity and greater consistency between the project appraisal document (PAD) and financing agreement and; (iv) revisions to the project results framework and indicators. It is expected that the restructuring will streamline and clarify responsibilities of sector ministries, and provide resources to ease transportation difficulties to enhance the delivery of agricultural and social services. No other changes are to be made to the project's activities, procurement, and financial management and safeguard arrangements. The changes have been necessitated by: (i) prolonged unsatisfactory implementation performance by the executing agencies; (ii) excessively slow disbursement compared to initial projections; (iii) difficulties in getting contracts and acquisitions underway; and (iv) the need to scale up feeder roads construction to catalyze the delivery of social services, boost agricultural production and the rural economy. The restructuring was identified during the November 19-21, 2008 implementation support mission. A restructuring mission was subsequently fielded during April 1-8, 2009 and agreement reached with the government on the nature and content of the restructuring.

title: SL-Public Sector Pay & Performance(FY12)
description: The objective of the Pay and Performance Project are to improve competitiveness in pay, performance management and accountability of, and increase staffing of middle and senior staff in, the civil service in Sierra Leone. There are two components to the project. The first component of the project is support to the Government of Sierra Leone's (GoSL's) Reform Program. This component supports the three reform areas (pay reform, recruitment and staffing and performance management) identified in the GoSL's flagship Public Sector Reform Program 'improving productivity through management and pay reforms' (the GoSL Program) which was approved by the President on May 1, 2012. The GoSL's pay strategy approved by Cabinet in February 2011 sets out a comprehensive approach to reforming public sector pay over a five year period. It recognizes that remuneration should be commensurate with the responsibilities of the job, which will require that a comprehensive job evaluation and grading exercise is completed before enhanced pay is introduced in a new pay structure. In addition, the strategy envisages significant decompression of the pay structure which will allow professionals and managers to be remunerated more competitively, while maintaining an affordable and sustainable public service wage bill in relation to GoSL's recurrent revenues. The second component of the project is technical assistance (TA). The TA component will complement the first component by financing selected inputs for which the GoSL has requested more intensive supervision by the Association or for which resources may not be readily available in the GoSL budget. This component will finance goods, consultancy services, non-consulting services, monitoring and evaluation, training, study tours and workshops. Given the importance of effective and continuous information sharing on the reform activities within and outside the government the GoSL proposes to develop and implement a strategic communication program.

description: The development objective of the Social Safety Nets (SSN) Project for Sierra Leone is to establish the key building blocks for a basic national safety net system and to provide income support to extremely poor households in Sierra Leone. The project has three components. The first component, development of systems for implementation of social safety net interventions objective is to put in place the building blocks of a basic national safety net system in Sierra Leone. It will finance the following activities: (i) design of a targeting system; (ii) development of a beneficiary registry; (iii) development of a management information system (MIS); (iv) set-up of a payment system; and (v) development of a grievance redresses mechanism (GRM) and anti-corruption measures. The second component, cash transfers to extremely poor household's objective is to provide income support to extremely poor households. The third component, project management and capacity building have the following two sub-components: (i) project management, to ensure efficient project implementation. It will finance routine project management for the delivery of cash transfers, and staff and operational costs related to development of SSN systems, and (ii) capacity building, to provide capacity building to key stakeholders involved in the implementation of the project. It will finance: knowledge exchange events; program and line ministry staff social protection (SP) training; line ministry equipment, goods, and services (including line ministry staff travel costs and technical assistance (TA) support); and studies linked to implementation of cash transfers as well as studies to enhance the social protection dialogue in Sierra Leone.

title: PFM Improvement and Consolidation
description: The objective of the Public Financial Management Improvement and Consolidation Project for Sierra Leone is to improve budget planning and credibility, financial control, accountability and oversight in government finances in Sierra Leone. The project has five components. (1) Enhancing budget planning and credibility component will strengthen the macro fiscal forecasting and public investment functions of government to improve overall budget planning, and manage systems and procedures for budget formulation. (2) Financial control, accountability, and oversight component will strengthen financial control in government, improve accountability systems and practices, and enhance independent and public oversight in the management and use of central Government public finances. (3) Supporting the strengthening of revenue mobilization and administration systems component will strengthen revenue policy and oversight of revenue collection, improve the efficiency and integrity of revenue administration to increase domestic revenue, and integrate revenue systems within the overall PFM system. (4) Strengthening local governance, financial management and accountability systems component will improve the financial management systems in local councils, and strengthen the accountability and oversight institutions to contribute to enhanced service delivery efficiency and effectiveness. (5) Public Financial Management (PFM) reform coordination and project management component will ensure a continued strong institutional framework to coordinate and oversee the implementation of the PFM reform strategy as a whole as well as manage the implementation of the proposed project.

title: SL-Energy Sector Utility Reform
description: The objective of the Energy Sector Utility Reform Project for Sierra Leone is to improve the operational performance of the national electricity distribution utility. There are three components to the project, the first component being distribution utility capacity enhancement and performance improvement. This component will support the establishment of a fully functioning and effective national electricity distribution utility (utility) through a three-year performance-based contract for utility operation and management between the utility and a competitively selected firm (contractor) specialized in management of power utilities in developing countries. The second component is the improvement of electricity supply in urban areas. This component will support an extensive investment program targeting the rehabilitation and upgrade of the national distribution network from 33 kV to the low voltage level as a first step to improve the quality and reliability of electricity supply. Investments financed under the project will contribute to increasing the transmission capacity of the system, as well as to improving service quality and reducing technical losses in electricity distribution by upgrading infrastructure in line with demand requirements, thereby decreasing the frequency and duration of outages at the customer level. Finally, the third component is the sector planning assistance, project implementation support and monitoring and evaluation.

title: Growing enterpreneurs to fight poverty
description:
Micro economic activities including food production, petty trading, food processing, tools production, cooked food selling, carpentry, hair dressing, tailoring and dressmaking are key sources of livelihood  for most poor  families in rural Sierra Leone. Entrepreneurs involved in these activities are however confronted with multiple constraints to make a living out of it. Lack of access to credit facility, low business skills (planning, management and accounting) and poor markets for their products are among the key problems. SEND Sierra Leone Livelihood Security Development Programme (KLSDP), supported by Cordaid and Christian Aid, is empowering 4,669 small scale entrepreneurs to improve on their livelihood security in Kailahun district, East SL.    

The underlying project will be a new component of the KLSDP, a 24 month pilot scheme, aiming at developing sustainable and quality business services for 30 small scale entrepreneurs to enable them to establish profit making small scale enterprises. At least 60% of the project beneficiaries are expected to be wonen. The project will equip them with business planning, financial management, record keeping and marketing skills accompanied by coaching services and access to credit to implement their individual business plans. The project will be implemented by the existing local staff of the KLSDP supervised by a Small Business Development Officer (SBDO). In addition, the SBDO will mentor the three community credit unions to strengthen their internal controls and related management systems to better safeguard and manage members savings, microfinance funds and credit facilities for the occupational associations involved in the KLSDP. 


SEND-SL is based in Kailahun, one of the poorest districts of SL. SEND-SL is a new partner of ICCO, but ICCO has had partnerships with SEND West Africa and SEND Liberia. SEND SL was visited with FSAS and identified as an interesting partner, in line with our own strategic choice to focus on BDS. This pilot can serve as a learning model.

title: Combatting Cross-Border Child Trafficking
description:
The government of Sierra Leone in August 2005 passed into law an Anti-Human Trafficking Act. In 2007 a child Rights Act was enacted into law in parliament which promotes and protects the welfare and rights of children, including trafficking. In Sierra Leone, anecdotal evidence indicates that women and children are trafficked internally to Freetown, from neighboring countries and from border towns in Pujehun and Kailahun Districts to neighboring countries like Guinea and Liberia in particular for involuntary domestic servitude, street labor, and commercial sexual exploitation. Children are trafficked from rural areas to Freetown and some from the border towns within Pujehun district to Monrovia with false promises that they will be sent to school, but instead are forced to work on the streets. There have also been reports of trafficking for debt bondage and sexual exploitation in the mines in the interior of Sierra Leonean and Liberia, victims are also trafficked to other West African countries, the Middle East, and Europe. 

In Liberia former government and rebel forces trafficked men, women, and children to serve as porters, laborers, combatant, and sex slaves during the civil war. UNICEF estimates that the former warring factions included more that 15000 children. Armed groups also compelled people to mine gold and diamonds. A significant number of the traffic victims are reported to have returned home through the help of NGOs and UN organizations others are still in Liberia in places like Burmi Hills, where they have the gold mines. The government of Ellen Johnson is yet to make a policy statement on the issue of trafficking and child labor but there are hopes that she will make Liberia a better place.

It is against this background that  RADA, supported by WINROCK worked on a project to raise awareness of the hazards of child labour and child trafficking and the importance of education for children so as to effectively increase awareness and put the necessary community monitoring mechanisms and structures in place to effectively combat child trafficking

This project is therefore develop to build upon the successes of the completed project by strengthening the monitoring mechanism, capacity of communities to address trafficking issues, cross border initiatives and networks and educational placement for children enrolled in the quoranic schools who are in most instances victims of trafficking and child labour.  The project will particularly learn from and build upon the significant achievements of the Borderline Child Trafficking, which reached 123,709 beneficiaries directly and indirectly.

It is expected that 30 community teaches in 4 schools are trained in the hazard of child labor/traficking and are engaged as focal persons to mainstream traficking issues inot their teaching curriculum. In addition, 50 at risk and former traficked children are placed in educational facilities and supported with educational requirements (tuition and fees, learning materials, uniforms, and counseling services).

This project will be partly co-implemented between RADA and the Sustainable Livelihood Promotion Program (SLPP)-RADA's counterpart in Liberia.

title: Business Development Support Network
description:
According to UNDP published report, in 2012 Sierra Leone recorded one of the fastest growth rates in the region, with improvements in the time and cost to start a business. In 2011 the country ranked 61 worldwide in the “Doing Business Report”. Despite this progress Sierra Leone’s 2012 Human Development Index of 0.359 remains below the average of 0.475 for countries in Sub-Saharan Africa positioning the country 177 out of 187 countries and territories.  At the launch of Human Development Index report Ms. Seppo, Sierra Leone’s Country Director for the UNDP noted that investments in people’s capabilities, education and skills, pragmatic policies focused on job creation, women, youth empowerment and improvements in service delivery are fundamental “drivers of change” in order to achieve a strong Human Development Index.  

The growth and graduation of Small and Medium Enterprises represent an important vehicle in job creation and the goal of sustainable economic growth and equity throughout the country. Therefore strengthening the SME sector has a critical role to play in absorbing labor and generally expanding the economy.  The overarching objectives of the setting up of a National Business Development Support Network are to:

This project will provide support to 100 women led enterprises in business skills and outreach. In addition, the project will help establish a national business support network.

title: Sustaining the Reintegration of Children in Sierra Leone
description:
Realisation of rights for children in Sierra Leone is a big challenge as their wellbeing is undermined by exposure to violence, abuse, exploitation and neglect. Of the 2.4 million children in the country, 27% are identified as vulnerable. Around 11% is orphaned, having lost one or both parents; 18% of girls are married at age 15; 88.3% have experienced FGM/C; and 81.8% aged 2–14 years have experienced different forms of severe physical punishment. Nationally 18.2% of children in Sierra Leone do not live with biological parents that are alive. Children not living with their parents are more at risk for abuse, violence, neglect and exploitation. Though no reliable data exist, indications are strong that sexual abuse and exploitation is a fact of life for many girls. 

Child protection services have not had the desired impacts on children as they are disjointed, competitive and project based meaning that the resources are ineffectively and inefficiently used. For example even though there are 58 children’s homes or orphanages in the country the provision of interim care for children in need of care and protection has remained one of the most serious gaps in the provision of services for recovery and rehabilitation of child victims of abuse and children in conflict with the law. 

Alleged child offenders are often remanded with adults in prison as there are no alternative care provisions in place for them. Also victims of sexual abuse and violence and trafficking do not have access to safe homes where they can access services for their recovery. The lack of safe homes and other temporary care arrangements also means that victims of sexual abuse have to travel to and from their homes in rural areas to attend court in the district headquarter towns. As they cannot afford the cost of this travel, they will not attend thus hampering the proceedings.

To address the child protection situation in Sierra Leone as a whole and in Bombali, Bo, and Kenema district specifically, it is important to make a strategic shift from a project based approach that focuses on a specific vulnerability within a small category of children to a systems based approach that aims to provide services for the protection of all children. Through a systems based approach: there will be increased awareness about child protection laws and policies; improved coordination and use of resources; government and civil society capacity will be built; sustainability of interventions will be ensured; child protection programming will be more focused and integrated; children’s competencies, voices and participation will be promoted and strengthened; community based mechanisms will be linked to the formal child protection systems and; there will be increased accountability for fulfilling children’s rights.

This project proposals aims to strengthen the child protection system in Bombali, Bo and Kenema district focusing on some of the core elements of systems building; coordination, case management, strengthening of the child protection labor force, putting in place a robust data and information management system, empowering vulnerable families and rehabilitating and reintegrating children at risk.

The action will use innovative and locally appropriate approaches and technologies to improve food and income security of vulnerable populations, especially women and youth affected by conflict in Sierra Leone; thereby contributing to the realisation of MDG 1 (i.e. Eradicate Extreme Poverty and Hunger). 
This will be achieved through developing capacities of local partners and selected communities in Bombali and Kenema districts to enable them pilot innovative, cost effective and locally appropriate initiatives that are locally owned and driven in the production, value addition, consumption and marketing of organic fresh water fish and poultry.

title: Strengthening the capacity of Caritas Makeni and Caritas Kenema for effective delivery of services
description:
CAFOD has been working in partnership with the Caritas family in sierra particularly, the Caritas Kenema (CK) and Caritas Makeni (CM) since 1992. A number of projects aimed at community development, livelihoods and disaster risk reduction have been implemented during the course of the partnership. However there have been issues related to the capacity of the caritas family in Sierra Leone as a whole. Challenges have been in the areas of organisation governance, programmes implementation particularly monitoring and evaluation and financial management.  In as much as CAFOD has the accompaniment approach that is aimed at building the capacity of partners they work with, this has not been very effective and is rather supply driven rather than demand driven. 
In 2012, the CAFOD organisational assessment of Caritas Kenema and Caritas Makeni offices, the DRR midterm evaluation report and the CAFOD audit report came up with a series of issues relating to the capacity of both organizations.

description:
General trends in the Sierra Leonean political and governance scene indicate that women continue to significantly lag behind in representation at all levels.
Political party leaders and strategists argue that very few women aspire for political or community leadership positions and the few that do so lack the requisite education, skill and the charisma to succeed. 
The project intends to educate communities so women are able to participate, transform systems to improve women’s right; and move beyond the traditional economic empowerment of women. Specifically the project will build the capacities of local women to participate in local governance systems: chiefdom and district levels.

Le projet travaille à augmenter l'adoption de pratiques agricoles qui favorisent les moyens de subsistance durables, à améliorer l'utilisation des aliments sains, en particulier par les femmes et les enfants, et à renforcer l'efficacité et l'utilisation des services de vulgarisation agricole. Unrestricted funding is essential to the way we work; It provides us with the flexibility to carry out work that is not covered by grants restricted to specific projects. This enables us to be more innovative,  and work on activities that are crucial  in  maximising our impact but may produce results that are hard to measure.  For example, it can help us to empower communities, support inclusion, and influence decision makers such as local and national government. It can be used to build the capacity of our staff and partner organisations, to monitor, research and learn from our work and share learning with others.  Finally, it provides our programmes with financial sustainability to ensure critical work can continue where there are funding gaps and unexpected costs.

title: Country Programme - Sierra Leone (2013-2014)
description:
Hunger and malnutrition remain challenges in Sierra Leone,especially among children under five years old,in spite of free health care and scaling-up nutrition initiatives by the government. WFP aims to support these initiatives through its supplementary feeding and stunting prevention programmes.

Enrolment in primary schools in Sierra Leone has also been a challenge. According to the Government's Millennium Development Goals - Progress Report 2010,net primary school enrolment is between 62 and 69 percent. Gender disparity remains a problem as drop-out rates are high,especially among girls in their early teens. Improving education quality and access to education are a priority under pillar three of the Agenda for Prosperity. WFP aims to support this pillar through its school feeding programme and bridging the gender gap by providing an incentive related to girls' attendance in school and their completion of primary education.

Aligned with WFP Strategic Objectives 2,4 and 5 of WFP's Strategic Results Framework,the Country Programme (CP) focused on increasing access to basic education and promoting human capital development through school feeding,and improving the nutritional status of vulnerable children,pregnant and lactating women and people living with HIV or tuberculosis (TB) through supplementary feeding. In addition,the CP focused on building productive agricultural assets as well as helping to achieve adequate food consumption levels and nutritional status in most food insecure households through asset creation activities. It supported the government in accelerating the transition from recovery to longer-term development. More specifically,WFP's programme portfolio was aligned with the United Nations Joint Vision and supported the government in the implementation of its Agenda for Prosperity (AfP),which is the Poverty Reduction Strategy (2013-2018). Agriculture was clearly identified as the first pillar in the AfP,which WFP supported through Component 5 of the Smallholder Commercialization Programme.

title: PROYECTO: HACIA UN PLAN ESTRATÉGICO PARA MAKENI (SIERRA LEONA)
description: El proyecto nace de la colaboración existente entre las Universidades San Pablo CEU de Madrid y Universidad de Makeni (Unimak), dentro del Proyecto "Apoyo al fortalecimiento de las capacidades educativas de la Universidad de Makeni (Sierra Leona)". Este proyecto, con vocación de largo plazo, se ha extendido a otras estancias y ámbitos. En concreto, tras la realización de dos foros institucionales y numerosos contactos previos, se arranca un proceso de planificación urbana y territorial para la ciudad de Makeni. El trabajo, desarrollado principalmente por la facultad de Arquitectura del CEU, implica a la Universidad de Makeni, al Ayuntamiento de Makeni y a otras universidades socias en Madrid. La aceleradísima expansión urbana, los importantes déficits en infraestructuras, los retos ambientales y productivos, las carencias en una formación cualificada en planeamiento urbano y la necesidad de dotarse de un marco global para la toma de decisiones, son algunos de los elementos críticos que justifican el proyecto. La facultad de Arquitectura del CEU se ocupa del campo puramente técnico, pero en contacto directo con la Universidad y Ayuntamiento de Makeni. En enero de 2014, Unimak, CEU y Ayuntamiento de Makeni firmaron un documento que, a modo de acuerdo, comprometía la obtención de un Plan Estratégico para Makeni en enero de 2015. El trabajo, pretende sentar las bases del crecimiento futuro de la ciudad y su territorio, anticipando sus principales desafíos y aportando propuestas críticas y operativas desde una aproximación transversal. En paralelo, en un país como Sierra Leona, sin facultades de arquitectura ni de planeamiento urbano, el trabajo que vincula a las Universidades es una oportunidad de generar conocimiento. No en vano, la Universidad de Makeni tiene entre sus planes de futuro abrir nuevos grados en estos campos.

description:
In collaboration with the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology (MEST) and targeted communities, this project will support 21,060 marginalised girls at-risk of dropping out of Basic Education in five rural districts of Sierra Leone to access education and stay in school with improved learning outcomes. It also seeks to improve learning, retention and attendance for all 62,631 girls and 71,889 boys currently enrolled at targeted schools.
